Text: This pocket guide was launched in January 2022 by Angel the Nameless and Mik the Maker. It was Angel's idea! :-)
Reach out to Swords of Light on Parkog!

[image]Forge of Empires is a browser and mobile app based strategy game that lets you create your own city and mature it from the beginning of the Stone Age onward throughout the centuries. 

But you know that already. It's why you're here. In our view, the best source of information you can find on the topic of Forge of Empires, is the official wiki site. Use the search function well.

[link:Forge of Empires Wiki]

Additionally, we suggest the official support forums. Good search features.

[link:Forge of Empires Support Forums]

Although this pocket guide can be read top to bottom as a book, you may use the drop-down tool at the top to jump to sections, or use the links in the next section to jump ahead.

Forge on!

[image]At its core, FoE is essentially a story of constant creation and exchange of the various currencies in the game in order to expand and improve your ability to create and exchange even more, while increasing the size, scope, and ultimately the coolness of your city! Your city is your garden, which requires constant poking, prodding, potting, and occasionally tossing, and should also be thought of as a long-term project. Resist shooting up through the ages or planting every Great Building that comes along. Like a garden, you need to take the long-term approach. Build up the soil. Make your troops stronger. Make your buildings more profitable. Basic play involves logging in and performing these functions at least once a day, clockwize around the board: · Checking in on and acting upon any active Quests going on -- including the Story Quests, Daily Quest, Event Quests or Rival Challenges · Collecting coins, supplies, goods and Forge Points from the Buildings in your City, as well as any incidents laying around in the grass, shoreline, or city streets · Looking in on the Antique Shop for any items to buy, and keep up your steady selling of unwanted inventory so you can buy new stuff and Building upgrade kits · Checking in on your Tavern, collecting if you've filled it, doing your upgrades if any · Checking in on your cultural settlements, like Vikings, Egyptians, Japanese, Aztc, etc. BTW, the Questline in settlements counts towards your city's "complete x number of quests" · Fighting or Negotiating in Guild Expedition (GE), Guild Battlegrounds (GBG), Quantum Incursions (QI), and maybe also Player vs Player (PvP) · Checking in on the Message threads and interacting with your Guild mates and friends — perhaps the most fun! · Performing exchanges in the goods trade threads, or posting Great Buildings (GBs) in the swap or 1.9 threads · Performing updates on buildings, expansions, layout editing, planting and otherwise tinkering with your city · Doing Research in the research tree -- but please think about staying in your current age a little longer and concentrating on your troop strength and city/GB upgrades · Working your way through the continent Map · Aiding all friends and guildmates, and visiting all taverns In this Pocketbook we will touch on all of those things and more, all written by your own guild mates, paste and current. Woot!

[image]Joining a Guild is an important decision. Early on in their FoE life, some players choose to move from Guild to Guild frequently, Motivating & Polishing (M/P), picking up Great Building Blueprints and gold coins, potentially friending some of the members, especially if they have red table cloths in their Taverns. But, eventually every player will choose a Guild of their liking and hopefully stay there for a while. A guild that matches their playing style, and that they feel has friendly members that will help them grow their city.

Some Guilds have requirements, such as completing level 1 in GE; fighting a minimum amount in GBG; owning certain Great Buildings (GB) at a certain level; minimum donations to new GBs in the Sticks to Bricks channel; logging in a certain number of times per week or even day; etc. These types of Guilds typically do very well in helping advance your city, with the understanding that you will give back to your Guild as well.

How to Grow Your City by Growing Your Guild [image]One of the easiest ways to generate Forge Points as well as buildings that create FP and fighting boosts (and also goods for your guild) is by fighting or negotiating in Guild Battlegrounds. And the cheapest way of getting those FP and buildings is for your guild leaders to put down as many siege camps as possible on the GBG map. Unfortunately, siege camps are paid for through the guild Treasury, which consists solely of goods that guild members put into it. Turns out the easiest way to consistently build the guild treasury is to have an Observatory and an Arc (and the Statue of Honor or Great Elephant you can win in GBG, and a few more Event buildings) built in your city. When you collect from these buildings they automatically deposit goods into the treasury for you. The higher they are, the more they give. Some guilds require you to have both Arc/Obs in the ground and at least at level 10. Having these GBs creates a sort of “circle of life” flow of resources where your investment in the treasury allows the guild to buy siege camps in GBG, which dramatically reduces the cost of fighting or negotiating to you, which allows you to play GBG longer, which allows you to to win more rewards, such as Forge Points and awesome buildings like Statues of Honor and Royal Elephant. It is very possible to win hundreds of FP in one session when there are a lot of siege camps installed and your troops have good fighting bonuses, which can help you invest and quickly grow your city. But each camp costs the Guild some goods, which can only come from you. So, in a way, it’s actually a selfish thing to install both an Observatory and an Arc. You’re not doing it for the guild. No, no, no. You’re doing it for you. Think of it like paying for the motor oil which you will put in your motor. It just runs better. So, build and level both an Observatory and an Arc, and plant and keep leveling any GBG-building, like the Statue of Honor or Great Elephant. You’ll be glad you did, and so will everyone else.

[image]Being a member of a Guild provides many benefits, including having access to the chat and trading threads in the Messaging system; and almost more importantly, being able to play Guild Expedition and Guild Battlegrounds, both of which costs the Guild Goods from their Treasury to keep things going. And so, being able to "pay back" or help keep the Guild Treasury well stocked is very important.

Either make frequent donations to the Treasury, manually, or plant Buildings that automatically create and pay Goods to the Treasury for you. These buildings include GBs the Arc, and the Observatory, as well as the GBG Special Buildings Statue of Honor and the Great Elephant, and the Egypt settlement's Special Building Royal Bathhouse, and Viking settlement's Timeless Dojo, as well as certain settlement Emmisaries.

Having these buildings in your city, maximized in levels, will go a long way towards making you an important member of your Guild, as well as ensure its health and competitiveness.

Your guild membership costs the guild 10 (2 of each) from Iron Age goods, then 60 (12 of each) from EMA goods, etc. WEEKLY.  Yes, weekly because that is what your guild is tasked to pay in fees to open up GE, without which you can't get the ratings that provide guild benefits, like free weekly FPs in your Town Hall or reduced costs for building materials or reduced times for military recruitment/healing.  That is why you joined the guild, is it not?  To enjoy the benefits?  Ten goods per day sounds like reasonable terms of support, once you get your city going.  THEN if you want to contribute goods to the Treasury from lower eras, have at it!  You'll find the amount needed to support your current age/era will gradually increase until in the Space Ages you'll be contributing 385/week.  This is why owning an Observatory, Atomium and an Arc are so important.

[image]It has been said that Forge of Empires is not a sprint, but rather a long stroll, walk or jog. Running up through the ages of the game is widely considered not the best strategy. Instead, aging up to Early Middle Age (EMA) quickly, then staying there for several months building up your fighting units and your inventory has proven to be a successful strategy. In this age you can easily fight GE and GBG and get some Great Buildings in the ground.

Going forward, whenever you advance to the next age (aging-up) you should make sure you have enough FP in the bank, and all the coins and supplies required to get through the Research Tree quickly. You can determine what it will cost in the table, below.

What most players do, once they've decided to camp out in a particular age is sit at the very end of the Research Tree, not opening even the first item in the next age, and slowly amass the resources to be able to run through the research items in one shot, then go back to the city, rip out all the troop camps and replace them with the new ones of your new Age, and start building up your units.

Tuesday at 8:00 AM eastern US. Why? That is when the next GE starts, and who you fight in GE is based on the Age you were in when you started playing it. As you may know, in level 1 and 2 of GE you are always fighting against units from the previous ages. That means, if you step into GE, do even just one encounter, then start your Age Up right away, you will have fighting units several ages above those in GE level 1 and 2, making it super-easy to get through GE that week!

In addition to each age costing Forge Points, Coins and Supplies to complete, you will also need to spend Goods to clear each item in the Research Tree. Great Buildings are an important aspect of FoE. These "great" buildings impart your city with many important resources, including people and happiness, coins, supplies, goods, Forge Points, and fighting unit bonuses for both attack and defense. Having many high level GBs will allow you to afford more of everything else, and grow your city faster. Acquiring GBs and "leveling them up" will be one of your most consistent and never-ending tasks. Bigger, more mature cities wind up with almost no Houses or Goods Buildings, and are mainly made up of GBs and Special / Event Buildings.

Read more about [link:Great Buildings on the Wiki]

[image]Before you can plant a GB in your city, you will need to obtain a full set of nine Blueprints for that building. These can be gotten by Polishing or Motivating your Guildmates, friends and neighbors, playing GE (rewards), picking up "incidents" laying around your city, or by winning positions on another player's GB by investing Forge Points.

The most efficient way to obtain blueprints is through the 1.9 thread, or, if you're a very new player and need help getting your first prints, in the Blueprints thread where other guildmates typically post a building that needs only a small handful of FPs to level, effectively giving you Position 5 for next to nothing, mainly so you can get the prints. If you are looking to build a specific building, simply ask in the main Guild thread.

When you get your first full set of prints for a Great Building, any good Guild will have a "Sticks to Bricks" thread, allowing you to "share" your brand new building (or GB lower than level 3) by clicking the yellow button and choosing the building. Guild members will then proceed to donate FP to help get your GB off the ground.
For when you have low cost positions to be filled on your Great buildings. State if you want your building flipped or not. Good deals are welcome here. Help newer players get cheap blueprints.

When leveling your Great Building, the goods it produces are instantly available and the timer is then reset. With this in mind, you can double dip by first collecting the goods from your Great Building, then flipping it, then collecting the goods again. For this reason, be sure to control when your Great Buildings are leveled up and in general, do not flip other players' Great buildings either.

There is a suggested and prefferred order of acquring GBs that focuses on improving your fighting units while also increasing your Goods, Supplies, Coins and FPs. These are...

· The "Fighting Trinity" of Great Building: the Statue of Zeus, Castle del Monte (CdM), and Cathedral of Aachan (CoA), each raised to level 10, will improve your fighting units attack bonus to 90% (30% each), which nearly doubles both your attacking army's attack and defense points.
· Once you have your Fighting Trinity to 10 each, get the Alcatraz (Traz), which will give you random troops from the fighting camps you have in your city. Raise this GB to 10 as soon as you can, then begin rotating through the four fighting GBs, raising the levels of each as high as you can go. Generally bringing them to 30 each as your next goal.

If you're looking for GBs that specialize in providing Forge Points, you will want to plant a CdM first (as part of the Trinity), then Cape Canaveral, Innovation Tower, Arctic Orangery, and the Kraken. Each of these buildings require goods from their ages.

[image]Of all the GBs out there, this is arguably the GREATEST Building. It not only provides Goods for the guild every day (like the Observatory) but also increases your bonus FP back when you win a position on someone else's GB when investing.

As your Arc gets leveled higher and higher, your bonus increases more and more, till you get your Arc to level 80. At this point you will receive back every FP you invested in anyone's GB, as long as you use the 1.9 method. That means you can very easily support your guild mates' GB efforts without it costing you a single FP.

[image]Every Great Building has what is called a "sweet spot" where the number of Forge Points a building owner needs to invest to level-up a building becomes very low. This is typically between level 30 and level 60. When a player's GB, especially the Arc, gets to level 30 they should begin to participate in these leveling parties.  Swords of Light has a Rave thread where any player can call a Rave for right there and then, or ask for a scheduled on where more players might be available to participate. Sometimes many players will want to level up their GBs, and so you take turns, doing one player's building for a few levels, then someone elses. Players who join the Rave to invest will call out their preferred positions using the 1.9 scoring method, and bring a GB up a level in about one minute. With a minimal amount of time and FP one could raise their GB up ten levels per Rave.  Rave Earnings: Raves are also a great way to earn tons of medals for city expansions, as well as tons of blueprints so you can level your building up even more.

The Alcatraz is a valuable Great Building you'll want to build soon after building your [link:Trinity]. It generates unattached troops based on existing military buildings in your city, even if they are not attached to a road! Make sure one of those military building is a rogue hideout to build your stockpile of rogues.

[author:Written by Janus Dialecticus]

Should you keep it and push it past level 10? At level 10, you have a 1/4 chance to repel two attack plunders on your city. So, if you’re like me and aren’t attacked too often, it’s kinda nice when you block the plunder. I stopped at 10 just to focus on other more important buildings, but I do plan to come back to it at some point. It seems statistically a better focus of effort than all of the defending unit boosts from other buildings, not to mention a space saver in that regard, too. You can repel plunderers in a 3x3 and not worry about defense unit boosts. Consider how many squares you dedicate to just city defense. If you push your GT high, you could reclaim them.
Don't.

This is a unique Great Building in that the only thing it provides is Goods for the Guild (GG) as well as some bonuses for GvG (Guild Versus Guild -- an alternative to GBG). This small 3x3 building does not cost much to raise, and as it gets leveled higher and higher, it provides more and more Goods for the Guild. Many guilds out there make this GB a requirement to ensure the Treasury is never empty.

We are pushing for low-age members to have an Observatory to keep our treasury running, if they don’t already have a building that automatically donates to the guild treasury (Obs, Arc, SoH, Elephant, etc). The Obs is easy GB to get goods for, but prints are always hard to find.

Some new players will think they can play FoE by only negotiating, and that is indeed an important way of getting through GE and GBG as well as the Map, but after a while, if you have focused your attention on getting the Fighting Trinity GBs (Zeus, CoA, CdM) up to level 10, you will soon find that fighting is the easier and cheaper option. In fact, the true sign that you are ready to age-up is if you can successfully auto-battle your way through all four levels of GE.

When to Auto-Battle? If you see that your army is way over-powered for the units you need to fight, then autobattle. It's quicker and you probably won't lose any units.

Some Fighting Tips: If the opposing army has no artillary, such as Catapult, Trebuchet, Cannons, etc., and no Mounted Archers, or basically no units that can attack from afar, then you can just skip your first turn or two and let them come to you. "Wait 'till you see the whites of their eyes", and all that. You will be able to attack them once they are nearer.  If the opposing army has artillary or any other shoot-from-distance units, you need to run like hell across the field of battle to get to them before they pick off all your units. Leave a few units in the middle of the field, while sending the majority of them after the artilary.

Fighting Boosts: If you are in the upper levels of GE or attrition has gotten high in GBG, you can go to the Tavern shop and buy some bonus attack, or your inventory to see if you have any fighting boosts there.

Rogues are special fighting units that have no defense on their own, but can pack a serious wallup, typically killing on the first strike... until they've been hit for the first time, at which point they "turn into" one of the other non-Rogue units in your current standing Army.  For instance, if you have three Heavy Infantry and five Rogues (Mik's favorite combination for tough battles) if one of your Rogues gets hit, it will sustain no damage, and instead turn into a Heavy Infantry unit, since that's all that's on the field that it could turn into. It then acts exactly like a normal Heavy Infantry unit. If there is nothing left but Rogues, it will likely die, since it cannot turn into anything else, and Rogues have no defense. Thus, going into battle with only Rogues dooms them all. Going into battle with seven Rogues is also risky in that you need to protect the one non-Rogue unit from dying.

When you are ready to work on your Great Buildings, please consider using the [link:1.9 threads]. The swap threads might be easier to understand, a 1:1 forge point trade, but you are greatly overpaying to level your own GB. By adapting to the 1.9 method early, leveraging your position rewards, it will save you a lot of FP every level!

In FoE, many Guild members start helping each other by swapping FPs on their Great Buildings, "GB"s. SoL has small swaps 5, 8, 10, 20 that allow you to place FPs on someone else's GB. Larger swaps of 30, 50, and 100 for those who have larger amounts are also available.

When using the Swap threads, your GB is getting boosted and you are helping another Guild Member to get the next level, while providing you the opportunity to get back some of your FPs, plus medals when your fellow Guild Members GB levels, if you swap enough to secure a position (P1,2,3,4,5). Here is a FoE guide for [link:Swap Threads Etiquette], that gives you insight into why they are popular, usage, tips, etc.

With our Guild, the way you post to a Swap Thread is pretty simple. To secure your spot you post the GB you want someone to add FPs to, then you add the appropriate fps on the GB that is posted before yours.  A simple tip for newer members, target GBs at lower levels, you have a better chance at getting a reward position.

That being said, the main reason for swaps is to move your GBs and have an opportunity at additions rewards. As a caution, never over-swap, only put in the required amount. Overswapping is not permitted.

Lastly, we are encouraging all players at any age to learn the 1.9 strategy, and for senior players to minimize the use of swap channels. While this is an easy way to invest and be invested in, it is not as efficient as the 1.9 thread, where you invest FPs based on the number of FP you will win for achieving one of the five investment Positions. See the next article.

As a newbie, I did alot  of private swaps with ppl, this got me a pos on their Gb that I paid over time to get prints. U just have to be dedicated to contributing daily. I found ppl in guild that would do this and some on my friends list. Sniping for prints as a newbie is difficult u don't have the fp bank that larger players do. The BP thread is great way to get prints u need cheap. My best resource was event bldgs, play events and max those buildings out, well worth the space.

I’m only 1 yr FoE old, and remember the swap threads well. Lord Bobby, I feel your pain.  IN THE BEGINNING, There were very few Forge Points. Most of them came from the hourly dispensation. Your best bet was to post your favorite building to the 5 FP thread so you had a chance of getting BP off someone else’s building while you spent your 10-hour allowance to clear the bin for more free FP. These were lean times.  Your army sucked. Your GB sucked. You had no supplies and dammit you had no coins coming in. I remember an elder once saying never post FP to your own building. Always post to some else’s in the swap threads because someone would post back to yours, so it was like posting the FP to your own GB, with the possibility of reaping BP and medals for your troubles.  But, you are deceived. This is a long game. Choose your GB wisely, and do indeed post FP to your own. Like a bank account, you will eventually get to the right number per building, and others who troll the 1.9 thread will quickly post their P1, P2 etc on your building, and as you grow, your investment will shrink per level.  By this time, because you play the game and accrue other Special Buildings and Event Buildings, you will have more FP coming in every day, and with access to GE and GBG, where the real action is, it will grow still more.  Listen to what Donna says, and what Angel says, and Ryudn and Rakush. It is absolutely in your interest to play how you’re comfortable, but eventually, and soon, EVERYONE eventually abandons the swap threads and goes for ONLY the 1.9 threads. You just gotta get over the swap hump.  But if you’re a newbie, read Rak’s initial post

The 1.9 Method is the most efficient way to level up Great Buildings, saving both owner and investor Forge Points, while allowing investors to earn many prints and medals. Everyone wins.  BTW, 1.9 Method goes hand in hand with having the Great Building: [link:The Arc]. The higher level an investor's Arc is, the more bonus FP they are rewarded for each investment. Once their Arc reaches level 80, the bonus received for each Position taken on a GB matches their investment, meaning each investment is paid back in full. Get your Arc to 80!

[image:How to post and invest in the 1.9 thread]By investing in people's Great Buildings, you are guaranteed the position you claim. In other words, for your investment you will get FP, blueprints and medals. With an Arc level 80 you will get 100% of your investment back. The following is all you need to know to start investing in 1.9 threads: · Take positions in order, P1 before P2, before P3, etc. Wait for the position to open before claiming it if you want a lower one. · Call your position before investing. You can do this by calling the position number or copy/pasting the on-going 1.9 list and removing the position from it. · Ensure the 1.9 list is up to date with your claimed positions removed. If there are no positions left in the list, call "Clear" instead. · Invest the needed forge points right away. Etiquette If 2 people claim and invest for the same position, the second claimer loses by overpaying for the spot and potentially causing the Great Building to flip accidentally. If there are any collisions, work them out together; if the first claimer loses their investment, the second claimer that got the position owes the FP to the first claimer. If claiming spots on multiple buildings, please be specific in your claiming post to ensure no duplicate claiming.

The “1.9” is actually the multiplier of the reward to determine the cost of that investment. If you post your building in the 1.9 thread, you state that the cost to invest in your Great Buildings is 1.9 time the FP reward for that Position. So, for example, if someone invests in P3 of your level 8 Zeus, which 
has a reward of 10 FP, the cost to take P3 is 19 FP (10 x 1.9 = 19).

The basic premise of the 1.9 is this: each GB level costs you a certain number of Forge Points to "level up" to the next level. Fortunately, other players can help you with that by claiming positions for 1.9x their FP rewards. Those who take Positions 1-5 are rewarded with FP, blueprints for that building, and medals for city land expansions. The higher their position in the investment panel, the higher their rewards.

[image: 1.a Calculate and secure each position on your Great Building by investing the needed Forge points to prevent positions from being stolen]As the owner, you need to make sure each position is secured, from P1 down to P5 in that order. Securing means investing enough FP to prevent a random player from overpaying and stealing the spot from your investor. You can invest at your own pace, calculating for each position using tools or the following formula: Investor Contribution: Position reward FP x 1.9 Owner Investment: FP left to level the GB - (Investor Contribution x 2) The graphic 1.a explains how to calculate and secure each position, however an excellent tool to use to figure out players' investments, is [link: FoE Tools], which will also provide you the level posting showing investment costs. The following routine is how most people proceed with prepping their Great Building. Calculate → Secure → Post Position 1 and 2 in the 1.9 thread. Wait for them to be claimed. Repeat the previous step for Position 3, then again for Position 4 and finally for Position 5. If your Position 5 rewards only blueprints and a few medals, post it in our [link:GB Blueprint thread] for cheap instead to help our guild's newer players gain more prints.

• [link:Calculate and secure the position] you want claimed.
  • Copy the existing list if there is one. Add your Great Building to the bottom of list, each on its own line.
  • Post your positions from lowest to highest to make the list easier to manipulate, and so the highest position is ALWAYS on the right.
Example of GB entries:
Angel the Nameless Zeus 24 → 25 P2(152) P1(304) SparkD Arc p5(10) p4(57) Timber CDM P4(29) P3(105) If you are posting a building for less than 1.9, giving the claimer a deal, let them know. They will appreciate it. Angel Traz P5(1) - deal!

Sniping means paying less than 1.9 for a position. For example, if a position rewards 21FP, 21FP * 1.9 = 40FP; a sniper is a player that would pay less than 40FP to claim it. This can becomes an issue if you invest more than needed to secure one position. The following example is if your Zeus takes 100FP to level and P1 cost 40FP to be claimed. Securing P1 only: 100FP - 20FP owner investment = 80FP 80FP / 2 = 40FP to claim P1. Excellent, it can't be sniped! Securing more than P1: 100FP - 30FP owner investment = 70FP 70FP / 2 = 35FP to claim P1, the sniper cost you an extra 5FP and they can't be bumped down, since only 35FP remains before flipping the Zeus. The only way to avoid being sniped is to secure one position at a time, waiting for it to be claimed before investing to secure the next position. It is also why, as an investor, taking positions out of order is discouraged.

If you "One Up kit" it to keep with your current age, it becomes a valid alternative to production buildings of your age that have a bigger footprint. It also works with supply rush boosts. The Message Center is the best way to communicate with your fellow Guild Mates, as well as your Friends and Neighbors. This is how you coordinate Guild Expedition and Guild Battlegrounds efforts; Trade goods with other players; invest in other players' Great Buildings; or generally chat.

GBG is the best place to pick up a variety of awards, including Forge Points. There are two GBG boards, each running eleven days, starting every other Thursday: Volcano Board, the original, and Waterfall Board, which started in December of 2021.

GBG is an important part of any successful players routine, allowing them to win Guild Goods buildings like Statue of Honor and Royal Elephant, as well as their connecting roads and gardens. These special buildings not only help the player with fighting bonuses and FPs, but also create Goods to donate to the Guild, which is very important.

[image]Grey is our assigned color. That color represents our ownership, our progress. It’s just like GE in a way. You look for a sector owned by another guild next to one of our sectors and then fight or negotiate. Each sector goes to 130 or 160, depending on the league our guild is in this season. As our guild member, your role is to prepare sectors by focusing your fights (+1 pt) or negotiations (+2 pts) onto our targets, but never actually taking ownership of the sector. You should not concern yourself with flipping sectors at all, let our GBG Council handle this as we work in guild alliances to increase rewards all around. In our GBG thread, information about targets will be given so that we can move across the board effectively. Some sectors will have a marker on it, indicating we have a specific plan for it. Note: Regardless of markers, do not flip any sectors unless otherwise mentioned in the GBG thread. Hand: Do not touch the sector, we've reached our goal! Bullseye: Prioritize this sector! Do not flip the sector unless it's mentioned in the GBG thread. Gray loading flag or small gray badge: Prioritize this sector if there's no bullseyes on the board! Nothing: If there's no targets left, including in the GBG thread, you can attack any sectors that make sense. Read more about [link: Siege Camps].

When working in an alliance, guilds are normally assigned quads (sectors that start with the same letter). Crossload is a term used to indicate optional rewards by loading sectors outside the guild's assigned area for the season. Crossload sectors 20 pts away from max, rather than the usual amount.

[image]Managing your attrition is an important part of GBG. Attrition increases with every successful fight or negotiation. The higher your attrition, the harder GBG becomes. You can reduce the chances of your attrition increasing by focusing sectors next to sectors under our control with siege camps (or watchtowers) built on them. Attrition resets at midnight (server time) every day, so make sure you use it up before then.

Something to look out for is whether or not the surrounding sectors we own to the targeted sector (flat borders touching) have Siege Camps or Watchtowers. 

You can see by clicking the sector, then clicking the buildings button. Each adjacent SC we own reduces the probability of increased attrition by 24%, so hitting sectors with less than 3 siege camps is almost guaranteed to increase your attrition every time. 4 or 5 siege camps is optimal to keep your attrition very low throughout the day.

For those of you who are not active in Quantum Incursion, I recommend it to you.  Rewards are pretty nice and the reward at the end based on guild standing is nice.  My other city got a 500 FPs per guild member reward for finishing in the top 30 guilds at the end of the last tournament (I believe there are 6 sessions per tournament).  

Playing is pretty easy.  Every 11 day session, starting on alternating Thursdays, is like starting a new Iron Age city from scratch.  My recommendation is build 6 lowest level houses, 4 Butchers, 3 amphitheaters, 1 ballista and 1 archery.  You need to use the Quantum expansions to build all of that.  You collect coins from houses and supplies from butchers every 10 hours, and you have to collect to start the next 10 hour cycle,

Fighting is easy on the guild map.  Move yourself to the current node.  If it is a battle one (most are) my fighting recommendation is to use mostly ballistas.  If there are any catapults or ballistas in the army you are facing, you should be able to auto fight with 8 ballistas.  When facing any horses, I replace a ballista with an archer for each horse I face.  I cannot successfully auto fight in those circumstances.  Rather, I target horses first then archers starting with archers near the top of the screen.  Only try to build more archers or ballistas when you don’t have enough to fight in this manner.

If you lack the attack strength to be successful battling as I describe, see if you can build a forgotten temple - it offers QI attack and defense boosts.  You can also look for attack boosts in your inventory that have the little fist - those help in QI.  They are timed, so use them when you can do a bunch of battles in a row.

Negotiating Goods in FOE is a combination of puzzle-solving (like the game Mastermind) with logic, a bit of pattern recognition through experience, and plain luck. Negotiations differ depending on location and encounter level meaning they are slightly different in GE, GBG and in the settlements where they are offered.

There are some basic strategies that might help you win more often and while spending fewer resources - here’s a few:

— You can use your Tavern silver to buy 1 more turn for each negotiation in GE for a given period of time. This only works in GE and nowhere else.  Extra turns are not needed on the first few tries in GE since they can always be won in 3 rounds.

— Mostly, this is a process of elimination. This fact is best used slightly differently in 3, 4, 5 and higher box negotiations.

— Use the items that you are most willing to trade first. In the few challenges of GE try entering, for example, all coins if your supply is super abundant, then fill in the incorrect ones with supplies on the second try and finish any remaining boxes with goods on the 3rd.

— Observe the outcome each time you click pay to negotiate. An “incorrect” means that item is out of the negotiation, disabling that good from being choosen for the rest of that encounter.

— You can click to give up at any point and start over. In GE you will lose a turn but in GBG and settlements you can try over and over.  You will lose the goods that have already been negotiated but you might save others by avoiding a situation that can’t be won without a great deal of luck. For example, I always give up on a 5 place negotiation if the first try gives me back 4 incorrect and/or wrong person results.  I will have only 2 more tries to eliminate too many possibilities.  I might give up after a 2 second try if it looks like I’ll be unlikely to win on my last (but might keep going if I have an extra turn to use in GE).

Often when you give up in a negotiation, the next one will somehow be easier to solve.  If not, you will eventually get one (if you can afford to keep it up).

— Higher level/more difficult negotiations tend (stress tend) to want more goods and fewer supplies and coins.  Use this probability to increase your chances when you have to guess. When you get to level 4 of GE, negotiations will become very expensive, and even Medals will be brought to the negotiations menu of options

— Should you use diamonds for negotiations?  That depends on how many you have and how you really need/want to use them elsewhere.  It might be reasonable to use one if you are sure you are only going to have the correct choice on the next turn or, if you have spent loads of scarce goods on a 7+ box negotiation and you be pretty sure you can pick the right one on the next turn. (Let’s not get into sunk costs here lol). Maybe you have just a few seconds until a boost expires and you need to finish or something like that might call for diamond use as well.

— In GE the negotiations start to have more boxes and to cost more goods as you go further in, temporarily rolling back a little when you enter a new level. By the end of level 4 you will be spending 9 each of 9 boxes. This is where an extra turn comes in helpful, and likely diaonds. In GBG, you will be charged more goods per negotiation as attrition increases but the number of boxes will vary randomly.

— Negotiations will gain you Castle points each day in addition to those for fighting. The big GE towers give you extra.

Siege Camps (SC) reduce the amount of Attrition you will receive after each fight. The lower your Attrition, the easier it is to fight, ie; you lose less troops.

So, for example, if you look right now, sector C3X is open for fighting. Two of the adjacent sectors that we own (and we must own them for the SCs to help us) are C3Y, which has 1 SC, and C2S, which has 3. Combined, there is “4 SC support” total for the target sector.

Each SC will reduce the percentage chance that your attrition will go up a point by 24%. This means 4 SC gives you a 96% chance that your attrition will *not* go up by 1 point after each fight. This means you can fight 100 fights, and statistically your Attrition will go up by only 4 points, total.

Conversely, if you fight in a sector with no SC support, your Attrition will go up 1 point after every fight, making it very hard to continue fighting until the Attrition counter resets at midnight

The neighbors tab displays a random set of other players in this world in the same age as you. The list changes every two weeks. You can friend them, aid them, visit their city, snipe their Great Buildings, or battle them so you can plunder their city to grab one collection from one of their resources, whether it be goods, coins, or supplies. Likewise, they can do all the same to you.

BTW, you will always get a reminder of your relative power as a player by seeing where you are in your neighborhood. If you are far to the right with a high player #number, it is likely you will be plundered, perhaps frequently depending on the personality of the other players in your neighborhood. If you are far to the left with a low player #number, it is very un-likely you will be plundered. It also shows you have matured compared to your neighbors and should congratulate yourself.

To help stave off being plundered, which will absolutely happen to you early on in this game because it’s allowed and almost expected. A right of passage in a way. How you handle it is up to you, but complaints and pleading will do nothing. You need to protect yourself.

Having a Galata Tower built and leveled as high as you can helps a lot. Small buildings like Ritual Flame and others (look for the blue shields and swords) will make your defending army stronger. And speaking of defending army, look to the Army tab on the left and go through your units, clicking the blue tile for each one you want to assign to City Defense. You can have up to eight. Do not assign Rogues. Have an assortment of units, with an emphasis on the units with highest defense numbers.

If the event building you are about to place in your city is incomplete, make sure you have Store building kits just in case you need to reclaim the space in your city in favor of a newer, better building.

The entire questline is always provided in the [link:FoE Fandom Wiki]. Try to be aware of the upcoming quests to be best prepared. At the start of an event, it's always best to leave yourself some room or store some buildings to be able to use the following shortcuts to complete certain quests. Increase population - Build the 2x2 multistory house (EMA) for 80 pop in 20 seconds. - Delete production buildings that can be rebuilt fast. Increase happiness - Build the 2x2 pond decoration (EMA) for 126 happiness in 5 seconds. - Upgrade your roads for cheap. Collect coins - Delete production buildings you can rebuild or decorations. Collect supplies - Delete houses you can rebuild or decorations. Collect incidents Check the upcoming quests to know when to save your incidents for later collection. Otherwise, you can save at least 4 incidents until you log off as a backup.

1. Aging up and leaving no players in that age changes the goods instantly specifically for that age.

2. When a guildmate leaves the guild, it will only modify goods required of their age.

3. We get to see if aging up before reset + boot = recalculate at reset anyway. (We don't have a definitive on this one due to the person leaving also being Iron Age in the test).

4. If a player joins and leaves after the season has already started, no changes happen.

5. Bronze age players counts as Iron age players for good requirements.
In build mode, grab your Town Hall or your biggest building and sweep it around on your roads. This will automatically collect your incidents, therefore saving time and your eyes.

One up and renovation kits should be used sparingly. They will normally effect the following building stats: +population, +happiness, +attack/defense and the age of goods produced by the building. 

Normally, you'll want to increase your building's age if you don't need the goods of that age anymore. Something to also consider is previous age goods are harder to get, so don't rush this process to avoid any regrets.

Junk Shop tip: you may not realize it, but there are probably a lot of items in your inventory that you could sell, but they’re locked, and so don’t even show up in the selling list. Go to your inventory, click on the lock icon at the top, and scroll down to see what event goodies you received in the past, but will never use. Uncheck the lock box for the ones you want to sell. I just unloaded ten House of Horror selection kits. They each fetched top dollar, and TONS of gems. Woot!

It’s not cool to flip or even post on other guild member’s buildings, unless they’ve advertised or asked for it in a thread. If you have extra FP and want to try your hand investing them in other peoples buildings and there’s nothing in the threads, you can look to the neighborhood. It’s open game there.

Quick tip: if you see no timers over the Antique Dealer (aka Junk Shop) that means you have not seen the latest auction item, and you have nothing for sale happening. You should really always be selling something in the shop, set to 1 day, even if it’s just the cheap 140 coin stuff. Build up that bank. Every once in a while you’ll see something you want to bid on (auction) or buy outright from the shelves. And for that to happen, you need coins in the bank. Get in the habit of using that resource.

Article: GBs worth having, by rich rice
Text:
My present list of GB, in the sets/order I would build them:
  • A (Zeus, CoA, CdM), taking those to L51 before starting much else.
  • Then B (Arc, Traz, ToR, Obs),
  • C (CC, AO, SBC),
  • D ( BG, HC, Krak),
  • and E (TA, CF, and SV). (Finally, get a SC to L10 before you step into Arctic Future.)
Other popular GBs, which I used to own, but deleted, are ToB, LoA, GT, and DC. While there are good arguments for “early on” owning those, I figure that I no longer need them, as I have a strong group of event buildings that provide all the population, coins, supplies, goods, medals and happiness that one could ever need; thusly, I would not invest heavily in growing those if you have them. All the big guns that used to own Shrines, Farms, Fountains and Wishing Wells have probably replaced them with something better. I no longer own goods buildings and have just the necessary twelve supply buildings (mostly Blacksmiths) just for events. Given one more GV and I will probably no longer need army buildings. When I get my Arc to L100 and all the other GB to L80, I will probably be looking forward to just IT and Virgo, because you always need something to invest in. Cheers. That’s just my opinion. Feal free to comment on my city scape. P.S. I have been in the game for 874 days and my current daily FP is 807, not counting rewards from BG, HC, and fights in GE and GBG. (1,000 plus average). I urge everyone to get strong early in CdM, CC, AO, and Krak, as those alone can provide 300 FP/day while also building up your fighting machine. As I often say: “FP is the commerce that drives all growth.”

While it is obvious that beyond having the various starter buildings, like Oracle, Babel (which you will eventually get rid of), Lighthouse (which you should keep), and the must have Arc and Trinity of Zeus, CdM and CoA, some people think having a low level Alcatraz along with all the other buildings to make room for and feed is a worthwhile pursuit. Well, they are wrong, frankly. The Traz is such a massive building, and so expensive, that you should instead use that real estate for more barracks, and focus your FPs on your Arc and Trinity, at the very least until they're all at level 10, if not 20. It is better to have fewer but STRONG troops, than more weaker troops. You'll get your Traz. Just get the big four in first.

Btw, Tip O’ the Day: running short on expansions? Make the Continent Map part of your daily morning regime. After you complete the initial massive Old Ages map, each following map has a minimum of 2 expansions on it, except in the space ages where there are several smaller maps per age, each with a minimum of 1 expansion.

It is recommended that once you've built up your city enough so you're collecting more than 100 FP a day you should sync all your building collections to once a day. Use the crate on the left to collect all at once (a 5 FP charge, but worth it). Because the process of syncing everything up requires that you don’t collect on any buildings until they’re all bouncing and at a time of day you can reasonably be online consistently (ie, at 8:00 in the morning right after the Daily Quest renews, while you’re reading the paper in bed with your iPad, ahem), you leave yourself open to plundering on that one day, though it’s definitely worth the one-time risk. It also makes you want to replace all your 8-hr buildings with 24-hr buildings. This way you collect once a day, all at the same time, limiting your exposure to plundering, while also maximizing your FP on hand for investing in GBs.

TIP OF THE DAY: Go to your Inventory and search using the word Upgrade. This will give you all your building upgrade items. Click on each one to see if you have something that can be upgraded. For instance, I didn’t realize I had three Nutcracker Guardhouse upgrades and one Tree of Vitality upgrade! You may also have upgrades you don’t realize you had.

Get your credits flowing ASAP, you need them to mine the special good mars ore. All houses, don't worry about oxygen. Pack as many as you can with as few roads and collect regularly. Goods synthesizers are huge waste of your ore, event buildings for mars goods. Unlock both mars maps, collect ore, you will need to collect enough for SAAB-SASH so keep that in mind. 

Mars is the template for the remaining ages, wash, rinse n repeat. Lot of stocking for next ages. Unlock sentinels and only produce them they are your new hover tanks.

Tips for starting your Quantum Incursion city, starting at 8:00 AM server time every other Thursday.

- four Tile Roof Houses - for population and coins
- five Butchers - for supplies (or six, see below)
- three Amphitheaters - for euphoria (happiness)

Set up the Houses, three along the north east (top) wall and one along the right side of the town hall in an L configuration, leaving room for a road between the three and the one, connecting all four using five road tiles.

Set the three Amphs along the outer eastern (right) edge, no roads required.

Fill in the west (left) and southern (bottom) open area with the Butchers. You can fit in five. Be crafty with your roads, using minimal number of squares. They are expensive.

If you have 100 triangular Shards to spare, you can buy an expansion with no rocks close to your Town Hall and drop in one more Butcher, for six total. This will not affect your Euphoria, and you will gain an extra 9,375 supplies for a total collection of 56,250 tonight.

This should provide 75 (or 50) extra people while still boosting productivity to 150%, which is important.

Let this bake for ten hours, and tonight you’ll crank out:

- 46,875 supplies
- 37,500 coins

Collect everything and let it simmer overnight to collect again in the morning. 

If you added a sixth Butcher, you should now have enough supplies to swap an Amphitheater for an Arch, which provides much more Euphoria. Take out one Amphitheater and replace it with an Arch.

Keep collecting and replacing/improving your buildings until you have room, people and coin/supplies to drop in fighters. Mik prefers Legionnaires. Pick your favorite and use 8 of them so you don’t need to plant two barracks.

After another day, your city will be built up enough to pay for enough fighters to spend down your Quantum Actions, and keep pushing the frontier on the battle map. Keep checking in throughout your day to see if you have any play left.

Plant every Neo building you win. They are excellent and give your main city a serious boost.

How do the rewards in Quantum Incursions work?

There appears to be four different types of reward scenarios…

- “Rankings” button chest for end of the Championship (3 months)
- “Max” button with the chests you can buy at the end of each Incursion (2 weeks)
- “Difficulty” button showing what you can win for helping finish each level
- “Pass” button achievements for your own individual progress

———

The end-of-Championship “Rankings” chest we get when the six-Incursions Championship ends. We will likely be in 14th place, which will get us decent rewards, including 1,000 FP. Each. Yes, you read that right. Plus a bunch of Neo building stuff, and 60,000 Quantum Medals, which can be traded in for main city expansions. Collect them all!

———

The end-of-Incursion “Max” gets you two random FREE chests, and you can buy more. To buy all six Championship chests will cost 1500 Quantum Actions, which reward:

- 200 Next Age Goods
- 400 Current Age Goods
- 800 Previous Age Goods
- x fragments of Neo Colossus upgrade
- x fragments of Neo Botanical Garden level 1
- 400 Forge Points
- 25,000 medals

———

The end-of-level “Difficulty” rewards stack up each time we clear a level. With each cleared level we get more Neo building upgrades, with a chance at more upgrades somehow. All good stuff.

———

The as-you-play “Pass” personal progress bar gives rewards in an eight item loop:

- 150 Quantum Actions
- 10,000 medals
- 150 Quantum Actions
- 10,000 medals
- 150 Quantum Actions
- Finish Special Production
- 100 Quantum Actions
- Neo Colossus upgrade

These can be increased by purchasing either the Silver or the Gold pass bar for cash dollars. The one purchase will stay with you for the whole Six-Incursion Championship (about three months).

Bottom line, Quantum Incursions generously hands out Neo buildings that rock, and Quantum Medals that you can buy main city expansions with. If everyone pitches in all season, we can crack Level VI and get CRAZY rewards. If we can obtain Top-10 status on the Guild Rankings, we EACH get 3,000 FP and a boat load of Neo buildings.

Participating in Quantum Incursions is good for both individual players, as well as the guild as a whole. Please do your part.
